title: How You Can Benefit from Using Retinoids on Your Skin

content: When patients come to my office, the most common question asked is, “What is the best routine for my skin?” Hands down, I will always recommend a topical retinoid. I usually start my spiel with, “Topical retinoids are the gold standard for healthy skin.” Beyond their recognized benefits in acne, there is a strong anti-aging effect in their ability to even the skin’s texture and tone. This one product packs a big punch.

Topical retinoids are a class of medications that are molecularly similar to vitamin A, an essential vitamin crucial in normal body functions. It is a fat-loving molecule that readily absorbs into your skin. Retinoid use dates back to ancient Egyptian practices, using the liver (which contains retinoids) to treat night blindness.

In the 1960s, a synthetic form called tretinoin was FDA-approved for treating acne. It was later discovered there was an added anti-aging benefit of reduction of fine lines and overall improvement of skin appearance. In 1995, it was FDA-approved for the treatment of fine wrinkles, hyperpigmentation, and texture changes from sun damage.

content: The idea of topical retinoids can be overwhelming. With the ever-increasing number of over-the-counter (OTC) options available, it can be hard to choose the best one. Understanding some of the science behind the medicine can help guide your choice.

All-trans retinoic acid is the other name for tretinoin. This is the active molecule that binds to a receptor inside the cell. Through a series of biological events, the molecule activates certain receptors in your skin to achieve the desired results, which include increased cell turnover, decreased oil production, exfoliation, collagen stimulation, and decreased microcomedone (acne) formation.
There are four major categories of topical retinoids:

All retinoid forms, through a process of receptor activity and chemical reactions in the skin, are eventually converted to the active form of retinoic acid. The only difference is the body’s affinity for certain topical retinoids, which affects potency, efficacy, and tolerability. This accounts for why some OTC products are more effective than others. It is also important to keep in mind that the closer the retinoid is to its active form, the greater its potential for irritating.
bullets: Retinoic acid (or tretinoin, by prescription only)

sections.heading: Retinoic acid
content: Tretinoin is the only FDA-approved medication for photoaging or sun-induced damage. It is the most studied and longest-running topical retinoid on the market. Beyond its anti-aging effects, tretinoin and other topical retinoids are considered the gold standard for treating mild, moderate, and severe acne.

Despite retinoids being readily absorbed into the skin, it can take 8-12 weeks to see results. There are some other great uses for tretinoin. One study demonstrated the use of tretinoin 0.1% improved the appearance of early stretch marks, which are typically characterized as red or purple in color. Retinoids are also helpful in other conditions, like psoriasis or ichthyosis (extremely dry skin). Tretinoin comes in three different strengths: 0.025%, 0.05%, and 0.1%. There are comparable OTC options to tretinoin, like adapalene. They provide similar results but with less irritation. If you are interested in a tretinoin prescription, this can be prescribed by a medical professional. One product you can try is La Roche-Posay Effaclar Adapalene Gel 0.1% Acne Treatment.

sections.heading: Retinaldehyde (retinal)
content: Second only to tretinoin, retinal requires a one-step process to reach its potent form of all-trans retinoic acid. While more effective than its OTC counterparts, it can also be more irritating. Additionally, given its higher efficacy, this form is typically found at a higher price point. Here are some OTC examples:

Also referred to as all-trans retinol, this is the second most potent form of a topical retinoid. When applied to the skin in a two-step process, all-trans retinol converts into its active form, tretinoin. This is the most unpredictable of the retinoid family, as it becomes unstable when exposed to light and the stability of the molecule can be affected by other ingredients. It is slightly less irritating and usually found at a more affordable price point.
Some OTC products you can try include:
bullets: CeraVe Resurfacing Retinol Facial Serum for Acne Prone Skin

sections.heading: Retinyl ester
content: Retinyl ester is a group of retinoids that has the least absorption within the skin. Retinyl palmitate is the most common form of retinyl ester and is found in topical preparations and stored within the skin cells. Here are some examples:

content: Retinoid side effects are dependent upon how close they are to their active form. Side effects include:
Those who have more sensitive skin, with conditions like rosacea or eczema, may be more susceptible to side effects even with using milder topical retinoids.

Choosing to start a topical retinoid is always a good idea. Whether OTC or prescription, the benefits of topical retinoids far outweigh the potential side effects. I recommend starting slowly, with 2-3 nights per week.
bullets: Apply to a clean face, preferably using a gentle cleanser, like CeraVe Foaming Facial Cleanser.
Only use a pea-sized amount of product to apply to your entire face.
Finish with an oil-free moisturizer, like CeraVe Moisturizing Cream.
Repeat nightly and enjoy your beautiful, glowing skin!
